  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_biological_token, "fruits\\/yields")`

- cause of anger is the seed/source of an organism (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_biological_token_stats, "seed\\/source")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_biological_token, "seed\\/source", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_biological_token, "seed\\/source")`

- the presence of anger is the growth/birth of the organism (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_biological_token_stats, "growth\\/birth")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_biological_token, "growth\\/birth", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_biological_token, "growth\\/birth")`

- effect of anger is plants creeping out (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_biological_token_stats, "creeping out")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_biological_token, "creeping out", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_biological_token, "creeping out")`

- maintaining anger is fertilising the organism/plant (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_biological_token_stats, "fertilising")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_biological_token, "fertilising", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_biological_token, "fertilising")`

No single mapping could be singled out as predominant. The metaphorical expressions utilise different components of the structure of the [organism]{.smallcaps} frame family (e.g., [plant life cycle]{.smallcaps} and [animate entity]{.smallcaps}) to highlight different aspects of anger. Anger can be considered as a consequence of an event, or as a cause leading to another effect. The metaphor also includes expressions referring to the cause, existence, and effect of anger.


### [Anger is (un)veiled object]{.smallcaps} {#unveiled-tokenbased}

```{r mapping-hidden-token, message = FALSE, include = FALSE}
mapping_hidden_token <- filter(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, str_detect(CM_BROADER, "veiled object")) %>% 
  mutate(status = if_else(str_detect(MAPPING, "_"), "key", "no"))
mapping_hidden_token_stats <- get_metaphor_mapping_stat_typefreq(mapping_hidden_token)
mapping_hidden_token_discuss <- get_mappings(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, 'veiled object') %>% left_join(mapping_hidden_token %>% filter(status=='no') %>% select(LU, LU_GLOSS, MAPPING)) %>% filter(!is.na(LU)) %>% left_join(mapping_hidden_token_stats)
hidden_frame_stats <- happyr::get_frames("veiled object", df = marah, frame_var = "SFRAME", metaphor_var = "CM_BROADER", lexunit_var = "MP")
```


This metaphor is attested in the two approaches and occupies the lower rank in the salience tables (rank `r get_metaphor_salience_rank(metaphor_salience, 'veiled')` in the lexical approach, and rank `r get_metaphor_salience_rank(metaphor_typebased_salience, 'veiled')` in the corpus one). [Anger]{.smallcaps} is here construed as an object that the experiencer has control over in order to be displayed (i.e., expressed for others to perceive), or keep it hidden, hence perceptually inaccessible by others. These two inferences, which are re-cast as the mappings in the metaphor, are based on the [hiding]{.smallcaps} and [cause to see]{.smallcaps} frames.

Key mappings: `r get_key_mappings(mapping_hidden_token)`

- expressing anger is unveiling an object (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_hidden_token_stats, "expressing")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_hidden_token, "expressing", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_hidden_token, "expressing")`

- suppressing anger is hiding/protecting an object (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_hidden_token_stats, "suppressing")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_hidden_token, "suppressing", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_hidden_token, "suppressing")`

The main focus of this metaphor in the corpus dataset is on the externalisation or "unveiling" the anger as shown by the higher type and token frequencies of this mapping compared to the hiding of the object mapping. In contrast, in the lexical approach ([§\@ref(hidden-typebased)](#hidden-typebased)), the focus is on the suppression of anger (i.e., maintaining control by "hiding" the object). Overall, the [(un)veiled object]{.smallcaps} metaphor highlights the control and expression of anger.


### [Anger is physical contact/harm]{.smallcaps} {#harm-tokenbased}

The [contact/harm]{.smallcaps} metaphor is also attested in the lexical approach and ranks in the top-3 of the salience table ([Table \@ref(tab:metaphor-table-type-based)](#metaphor-table-type-based)), unlike in the corpus salience table. The metaphorical expressions evoking the [physical harm]{.smallcaps} frame capture the effect of anger. It impacts both the experiencer and other entities that become the target of angry person, especially when the Harmed_entity role of the frame is filled with entity other than the experiencer of anger. The following mappings are postulated for the metaphor.

```{r mapping-harm-token, message = FALSE, include = FALSE}
mapping_harm_token <- filter(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, str_detect(CM_BROADER, "harm$")) %>% 
  mutate(status = if_else(str_detect(MAPPING, "_"), "key", "no"))
mapping_harm_token_stats <- get_metaphor_mapping_stat_typefreq(mapping_harm_token)
mapping_harm_token_discuss <- get_mappings(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, 'harm$') %>% left_join(mapping_harm_token %>% filter(status=='no') %>% select(LU, LU_GLOSS, MAPPING)) %>% filter(!is.na(LU)) %>% left_join(mapping_harm_token_stats)
harm_frame_stats <- happyr::get_frames("harm$", df = marah, frame_var = "SFRAME", metaphor_var = "CM_BROADER", lexunit_var = "MP")
```

Key mappings: `r get_key_mappings(mapping_harm_token)`

- effect of anger is harmful effect (at others) (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_harm_token_stats, "harmful effect")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_harm_token, "harmful effect", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_harm_token, "harmful effect")`

- experiencing anger is physical harm (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_harm_token_stats, "experiencing")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_harm_token, "experiencing", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_harm_token, "experiencing")`


In Kövecses's [-@kovecses_metaphor_2000] [force-dynamic]{.smallcaps} system, the metaphor highlight the part where the experience of anger leads to experiencer's responses (e.g., directing the harm at others). This aspect is also an important part of the [anger is natural force]{.smallcaps}, [anger is subjugator]{.smallcaps}, and [anger is weapon]{.smallcaps} metaphor.

The difference in the two approaches for this metaphor is in the main meaning focus. The predominant types in the lexical approach focuses on the cause of anger. The expressions referring to physical touching or harm are used in the context of harming the candidate experiencer (i.e., causing the candidate experiencer to be angry) ([§\@ref(harm-typebased)](#harm-typebased)). In the corpus approach, however, the physical harm expressions are used to show the harmful effect when experiencing anger and when targeting that effect to others.

### [Intensity is luminousity]{.smallcaps} {#luminousity-tokenbased}

```{r mapping-luminousity-token, message = FALSE, include = FALSE}
mapping_luminousity_token <- filter(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, str_detect(CM_BROADER, "luminousity$")) %>% 
  mutate(status = if_else(str_detect(MAPPING, "_"), "key", "no"))
mapping_luminousity_token_stats <- get_metaphor_mapping_stat_typefreq(mapping_luminousity_token)
mapping_luminousity_token_discuss <- get_mappings(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, 'luminousity$') %>% left_join(mapping_luminousity_token %>% filter(status=='no') %>% select(LU, LU_GLOSS, MAPPING)) %>% filter(!is.na(LU)) %>% left_join(mapping_luminousity_token_stats)
luminousity_frame_stats <- happyr::get_frames("luminousity$", df = marah, frame_var = "SFRAME", metaphor_var = "CM_BROADER", lexunit_var = "MP")
```

Amongst the metaphors in the bottom five of the corpus-based salience table ([Table \@ref(tab:metaphor-table-token-based)](#metaphor-table-token-based)), [intensity is luminousity]{.smallcaps} has the highest token (`r get_salience_stats(metaphor_salience, 'n_token', 'luminousity$')`) but also the lowest types (`r get_salience_stats(metaphor_salience, 'n_type', 'luminousity$')`) and mappings (`r get_salience_stats(metaphor_salience, 'n_mapping', 'luminousity$')`). The metaphor is not attested in the lexical approach. Below are the mappings of the metaphor.

The key mappings: `r get_key_mappings(mapping_luminousity_token)`

- reducing anger is reducing the level of light (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_luminousity_token_stats, "reducing")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_luminousity_token, "reducing", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_luminousity_token, "reducing")`

The metaphor is based on LUs evoking the [darkness]{.smallcaps} frame, a perspective of the [luminosity]{.smallcaps} frame that characterises the amount of light from a light source. These frames are utilised in highlighting the ceasing intensity of anger. [Intensity is luminousity]{.smallcaps} is related to the [anger is fire]{.smallcaps} ([§\@ref(fire-tokenbased)](#fire-tokenbased)) but captures anger's intensity not via the degree of heat, but the amount of light.

### [Anger is person]{.smallcaps} {#person-tokenbased}

```{r mapping-person-token, message = FALSE, include = FALSE}
mapping_person_token <- filter(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, str_detect(CM_BROADER, "person$")) %>% 
  mutate(status = if_else(str_detect(MAPPING, "_"), "key", "no"))
mapping_person_token_stats <- get_metaphor_mapping_stat_typefreq(mapping_person_token)
mapping_person_token_discuss <- get_mappings(metaphor_tokenbased_mapping, 'person$') %>% left_join(mapping_person_token %>% filter(status=='no') %>% select(LU, LU_GLOSS, MAPPING)) %>% filter(!is.na(LU)) %>% left_join(mapping_person_token_stats)
person_frame_stats <- happyr::get_frames("person$", df = marah, frame_var = "SFRAME", metaphor_var = "CM_BROADER", lexunit_var = "MP")
```

This metaphor could be viewed as a soft personification of anger and is not attested in the lexical approach. It is based on LUs that evoke features of the [person]{.smallcaps} frame, which is a sub-case of the [animate entity]{.smallcaps} and [sentient]{.smallcaps} frames. 

Key mappings: `r get_key_mappings(mapping_person_token)`

- causing anger is inviting a person to come (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_person_token_stats, "inviting")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_person_token, "inviting", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_person_token, "inviting")`

- experiencing anger is being friend with/welcome by a person (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_person_token_stats, "friend")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_person_token, "friend", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_person_token, "friend")`

- reducing anger is dismissing the invited person (type=`r get_metaphor_mapping_n_lu(mapping_person_token_stats, "dismissing")`; token=`r get_metaphor_mapping_tokenfreq(mapping_person_token, "dismissing", lu_output = FALSE)`)

  - `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(mapping_person_token, "dismissing")`

Unlike the other personifying metaphors (e.g., [adversary]{.smallcaps} or [subjugator]{.smallcaps}), [anger is person]{.smallcaps} captures the causation and diminishing of anger, rather than the intensity and effect of it. The metaphorical expressions refer to actions and objectives that animate as well as sentient/cognising entities such as a person typically do. These includes welcoming, inviting, dismissing, and befriend or playing with someone. In a way, such actions represent anger as a superficially safe emotion to be with.

## Metonymy {#tokenbased-metonymy-salience-results}

```{r metonymy-category-tokenbased}
physiological_response_regex <- "(body heat|internal pressure|redness|breathing|visual interference|body hair|teeth biting|foaming)"
metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category <- metonymy_tokenbased_salience %>% 
  mutate(category = if_else(str_detect(METONYMY, physiological_response_regex), "physiological response", "social-communicative behaviour"))

physiology_type <- metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category %>% 
  filter(category == "physiological response") %>% 
  mutate(meto_stats = paste("[", METONYMY, "]{.smallcaps} (type=", n_type, "; token=", n_token, ")", sep = "")) %>% 
  pull(meto_stats)
physiology_type_total <- paste("*TOTAL~type~=", sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category == "physiological response")$n_type),"*; *TOTAL~token~=", sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category == "physiological response")$n_token), "*", sep = "")
physiology_type <- c(physiology_type, physiology_type_total)

social_type <- metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category %>% 
  filter(category != "physiological response") %>% 
  mutate(meto_stats = paste("[", METONYMY, "]{.smallcaps} (type=", n_type, "; token=", n_token, ")", sep = "")) %>% 
  pull(meto_stats)
social_type_total <- paste("*TOTAL~type~=", sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category != "physiological response")$n_type),"*; *TOTAL~token~=", sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category != "physiological response")$n_token), "*", sep = "")
social_type <- c(social_type, rep("", (length(physiology_type) - 1) - length(social_type)), social_type_total)

metonymy_tokenbased_category_print <- tibble(`social-communicative behaviour:` = social_type, `physiological response:` = physiology_type)
```

The corpus analysis of the metonymy now includes the token frequencies for the metonymies, in addition to their type frequencies. These metonymies are rank-ordered in [Table \@ref(tab:metonymy-table-token-based)](#metonymy-table-token-based) by their token frequencies.


```{r metonymy-table-token-based}
metonymy_tokenbased_salience_print %>% 
  select(-Aggregate) %>% 
  knitr::kable(caption = "Conceptual metonymies for [anger]{.smallcaps} (Token-based, corpus approach)")
```


```{r metonymy-tokenbased-typebased-comparison}
metonymy_tokenbased_typebased_shared <- intersect(metonymy_tokenbased_salience$METONYMY, metonymy_typebased_salience$metonymy)
metonymy_tokenbased_only <- setdiff(metonymy_tokenbased_salience$METONYMY, metonymy_typebased_salience$metonymy)
metonymy_typebased_only <- setdiff(metonymy_typebased_salience$metonymy, metonymy_tokenbased_salience$METONYMY)
metonymy_tokenbased_typebased_ALL <- unique(metonymy_tokenbased_salience$METONYMY, metonymy_typebased_salience$metonymy)
```

From the two approaches, there are total `r length(unique(metonymy_tokenbased_salience$METONYMY, metonymy_typebased_salience$metonymy))` unique metonymies, and most of them (i.e., `r length(intersect(metonymy_tokenbased_salience$METONYMY, metonymy_typebased_salience$metonymy))` metonymies [`r round(length(intersect(metonymy_tokenbased_salience$METONYMY, metonymy_typebased_salience$metonymy))/length(unique(metonymy_tokenbased_salience$METONYMY, metonymy_typebased_salience$metonymy)) * 100, digits = 1)`%]) occur in the two approaches. This suggests a rather consistent metonymic construal for anger, especially the [strong/aggressive verbal behaviour for anger]{.smallcaps} that tops the metonymy tables in the two approaches. This prominent metonymy can be considered consistent with Heider's [-@heider_landscapes_1991, 80, 116] psychological and anthropological study indicating that verbal abuse is one kind of outcome/reaction of anger (in addition to physical violence). The metonymies attested only in the lexical approach are `r paste(paste(paste("[", metonymy_typebased_only, "]{.smallcaps}", sep = "")[1:length(metonymy_typebased_only)-1], collapse = ", "), ", and ", paste("[", metonymy_typebased_only, "]{.smallcaps}", sep = "")[length(metonymy_typebased_only)], sep = "")`. Meanwhile, those identified only in the corpus approach are `r paste(paste(paste("[", metonymy_tokenbased_only, "]{.smallcaps}", sep = "")[1:length(metonymy_tokenbased_only)-1], collapse = ", "), ", and ", paste("[", metonymy_tokenbased_only, "]{.smallcaps}", sep = "")[length(metonymy_tokenbased_only)], sep = "")`. 

### [Strong/aggressive verbal behaviour for anger]{.smallcaps} {#verbal-tokenbased}

- `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(metonymy_tokenbased, mapping_regex = 'aggressive verbal', mapping_var = "METONYMY", metaphor_data = FALSE)`

This metonymy is the most salient in both approaches, having `r get_salience_stats(metonymy_typebased_salience, "n_type", "aggressive verbal", metaphor_data = FALSE)` and `r get_salience_stats(metonymy_tokenbased_salience, "n_type", "aggressive verbal", metaphor_data = FALSE)` types in the lexical and corpus aproaches respectively.

### [Aggressive visual behaviour for anger]{.smallcaps} {#visual-behaviour-tokenbased}

- `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(metonymy_tokenbased, mapping_regex = 'visual behaviour', mapping_var = "METONYMY", metaphor_data = FALSE)`

This is another metonymy that is also salient in the two approaches, ranked in the top-3 metonymies. However, the corpus dataset reveals significantly greater number of types (`r get_salience_stats(metonymy_tokenbased_salience, "n_type", "aggressive visual behaviour", metaphor_data = FALSE)`) compared to the lexical dataset (`r get_salience_stats(metonymy_typebased_salience, "n_type", "aggressive visual behaviour", metaphor_data = FALSE)`) (*p*~Binomial~ ~two~~-~~tailed~`r pval_print(binom.test(c(get_salience_stats(metonymy_typebased_salience, "n_type", "aggressive visual behaviour", metaphor_data = FALSE), get_salience_stats(metonymy_tokenbased_salience, "n_type", "aggressive visual behaviour", metaphor_data = FALSE)))$p.value)`). 

From the list of metonymic expressions above, one expression does not contain the target term [marah]{.smallcaps} but the context of the concordance clearly indicates that such expression has to do with anger.

(@pandangan_liar) *__Pandangan matanya liar__ dan memancarkan amarah yang meluap.* (ind_mixed_2012_1M: 575480)

In this example, the eyes both spurt out boiled over anger and show wild gaze.

### [Redness in the facial area for anger]{.smallcaps} {#redness-tokenbased}

- `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(metonymy_tokenbased, mapping_regex = 'redness', mapping_var = "METONYMY", metaphor_data = FALSE)`

This metonymy has significantly greater number of types (and thus ranked higher) in the corpus dataset (`r get_salience_stats(metonymy_tokenbased_salience, "n_type", "redness", metaphor_data = FALSE)`; rank=`r get_metaphor_salience_rank(metonymy_tokenbased_salience, "redness", FALSE)`) than in the lexical one (`r get_salience_stats(metonymy_typebased_salience, "n_type", "redness", metaphor_data = FALSE)`; rank=`r get_metaphor_salience_rank(metonymy_typebased_salience, "redness", FALSE)`) (*p*~Binomial~ ~two~~-~~tailed~`r pval_print(binom.test(c(get_salience_stats(metonymy_typebased_salience, "n_type", "redness", metaphor_data = FALSE), get_salience_stats(metonymy_tokenbased_salience, "n_type", "redness", metaphor_data = FALSE)))$p.value)`). The metonymic expressions indicate that anger causes such physiological effects of redness in the facial area of the experiencer.

### [Internal pressure for anger]{.smallcaps} {#internal-pressure-tokenbased}

- `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(metonymy_tokenbased, mapping_regex = 'internal pressure', mapping_var = "METONYMY", metaphor_data = FALSE)`

The [internal pressure]{.smallcaps} metonymy shares the same number of types between the two datasets (`r get_salience_stats(metonymy_tokenbased_salience, "n_type", "pressure", metaphor_data = FALSE)` types in the corpus dataset, and `r get_salience_stats(metonymy_typebased_salience, "n_type", "pressure", metaphor_data = FALSE)` types in the lexical one). The internal pressure predominantly goes with trembling body parts and voice.

### [Body heat for anger]{.smallcaps} {#body-heat-tokenbased}

- `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(metonymy_tokenbased, mapping_regex = "body heat", mapping_var = "METONYMY", metaphor_data = FALSE)`

The [body heat]{.smallcaps} metonymy is less productive in terms of its type in the corpus dataset (`r get_salience_stats(metonymy_tokenbased_salience, "n_type", "body heat", metaphor_data = FALSE)`) compared to the lexical one (`r get_salience_stats(metonymy_typebased_salience, "n_type", "body heat", metaphor_data = FALSE)`).

### [Violent frustated behaviour for anger]{.smallcaps} {#frustation-tokenbased}

- `r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(metonymy_tokenbased, mapping_regex = "violent frustated", mapping_var = "METONYMY", metaphor_data = FALSE)`

This metonymy appears to be less prominent in the corpus dataset than in the lexical one in terms of the number of metonymic expressions and, by consequence, the ranking. In the lexical approach, it is evoked by `r get_salience_stats(metonymy_typebased_salience, "n_type", "violent", metaphor_data = FALSE)` expressions (rank=`r get_metaphor_salience_rank(metonymy_typebased_salience, 'violent', FALSE)`), which is significantly greater than the number of expressions in the corpus dataset (`r get_salience_stats(metonymy_tokenbased_salience, "n_type", "violent", metaphor_data = FALSE)`; rank=`r get_metaphor_salience_rank(metonymy_tokenbased_salience, 'violent', FALSE)`) (*p*~Binomial~ ~two~~-~~tailed~`r pval_print(binom.test(c(get_salience_stats(metonymy_typebased_salience, "n_type", "violent", metaphor_data = FALSE), get_salience_stats(metonymy_tokenbased_salience, "n_type", "violent", metaphor_data = FALSE)))$p.value)`).

### Other singleton metonymies

There are `r nrow(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience, n_type < 2))` metonymies that only have a single type; they are (i) [`r filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience, n_type < 2)[[1]][1]`]{.smallcaps} (`r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(metonymy_tokenbased, mapping_regex = "crying", mapping_var = "METONYMY", metaphor_data = FALSE)`), (ii) [`r filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience, n_type < 2)[[1]][2]`]{.smallcaps} (`r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(metonymy_tokenbased, mapping_regex = "foaming", mapping_var = "METONYMY", metaphor_data = FALSE)`), (iii) [`r filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience, n_type < 2)[[1]][3]`]{.smallcaps} (`r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(metonymy_tokenbased, mapping_regex = "teeth biting", mapping_var = "METONYMY", metaphor_data = FALSE)`), (iv) [`r filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience, n_type < 2)[[1]][4]`]{.smallcaps} (`r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(metonymy_tokenbased, mapping_regex = "speechless", mapping_var = "METONYMY", metaphor_data = FALSE)`), and (v) [`r filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience, n_type < 2)[[1]][5]`]{.smallcaps} (`r get_lu_gloss_n_printed(metonymy_tokenbased, mapping_regex = "visual interference", mapping_var = "METONYMY", metaphor_data = FALSE)`). Two metonymies have greater number of types in the lexical dataset, namely [visual interference for anger]{.smallcaps} (`r get_salience_stats(metonymy_typebased_salience, "n_type", "visual interference", metaphor_data = FALSE)`) and [lip/teeth biting/pressing for anger]{.smallcaps} (`r get_salience_stats(metonymy_typebased_salience, "n_type", "teeth biting", metaphor_data = FALSE)`).

### Types of the metonymies (token-based dataset) {#metonymy-category-tokenbased}

From `r nrow(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category)` metonymies, `r nrow(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category == "physiological response"))` metonymies represent physiological responses (type=`r sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category == "physiological response")$n_type)`; token=`r sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category == "physiological response")$n_token)`), and `r nrow(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category != "physiological response"))` are of the social-communicative behaviour types (type=`r sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category != "physiological response")$n_type)`; token=`r sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category != "physiological response")$n_token)`).

```{r metonymy-category-table-tokenbased}
metonymy_tokenbased_category_binomtest_type <- binom.test(sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category != "physiological response")$n_type), sum(sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category != "physiological response")$n_type), sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category == "physiological response")$n_type)))

metonymy_tokenbased_category_binomtest_token <- binom.test(sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category != "physiological response")$n_token), sum(sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category != "physiological response")$n_token), sum(filter(metonymy_tokenbased_salience_category, category == "physiological response")$n_token)))

metonymy_tokenbased_category_print %>% knitr::kable(caption = "Two types of metonymies of [anger]{.smallcaps} (token-based dataset)")
```

As in the lexical dataset ([§\@ref(metonymy-category-typebased)](#metonymy-category-typebased)), the number of metonymies in the physiological response category are greater than the ones in the social-communicative behaviour. However, the social-communicative behaviour category in total still exhibits significantly greater number of types (*p*~Binomial~ ~two~~-~~tailed~`r pval_print(metonymy_tokenbased_category_binomtest_type$p.value)`) and tokens (*p*~Binomial~ ~two~~-~~tailed~`r pval_print(metonymy_tokenbased_category_binomtest_token$p.value)`) than the physiological response category. Therefore, the lexical and corpus-based approaches converge along these distributional aspects of the metonymies.

# Metonymical basis of [anger]{.smallcaps} metaphors {#metonymic-basis}

Three of the five physiology-based metonymies suggested by Lakoff and Kövecses [-@holland_cognitive_1987, 197] motivate the two principal metaphors for anger: [anger is heat]{.smallcaps} and [anger is heated fluid in a container]{.smallcaps} [see @rajeg_metafora_2013, 211-213, for the quantitative evidence for the prominent status of these anger metaphors in Indonesian]. These three metonymies are [body heat for anger]{.smallcaps} ([§\@ref(body-heat-tokenbased)](#body-heat-tokenbased) and [\@ref(body-heat-typebased)](#body-heat-typebased)), [internal pressure for anger]{.smallcaps} ([§\@ref(internal-pressure-typebased)](#internal-pressure-typebased) and [\@ref(internal-pressure-tokenbased)](#internal-pressure-tokenbased)), and [redness in the facial area for anger]{.smallcaps} ([§\@ref(redness-typebased)](#redness-typebased) and [\@ref(redness-tokenbased)](#redness-tokenbased)). In addition to these, there are other physiology-related metonymies ([Table \@ref(tab:metonymy-category-table-typebased)](#metonymy-category-table-typebased) and [Table \@ref(tab:metonymy-category-table-tokenbased)](#metonymy-category-table-tokenbased)) motivating other metaphors. The list below shows the relevant metaphors (from the two approaches) motivated by the physiology-based metonymies.

- [Body heat for anger]{.smallcaps} could motivate these metaphors:

  - [anger is heat]{.smallcaps}
  - [anger is fire]{.smallcaps}
  - [anger is heated fluid in a container]{.smallcaps}
  - [intensity is temperature]{.smallcaps} (corpus dataset; outside the top-20 salient metaphors)

The [heated fluid in a container]{.smallcaps} may also be motivated by the [internal pressure for anger]{.smallcaps} metonymy [@holland_cognitive_1987, 197], given that internal heat pressure could trigger the boiling over of the heated fluid.

- [Redness in the facial area for anger]{.smallcaps} could motivate these metaphors:

  - [anger is fire]{.smallcaps}
  - [intensity is luminousity]{.smallcaps}

- [Caressing the chest for anger]{.smallcaps} ([§\@ref(caressing-chest-typebased)](#caressing-chest-typebased)), [lip/teeth biting/pressing for anger]{.smallcaps} ([§\@ref(lip-biting-typebased)](#lip-biting-typebased)), [internal pressure for anger]{.smallcaps}, and [breathing difficulty for anger]{.smallcaps} ([§\@ref(breathing-typebased)](#breathing-typebased)) could motivate these metaphors:

  - [anger is contained substance]{.smallcaps}
  - [anger is pressurised substance in a container]{.smallcaps}
  - [anger is heated fluid in a container]{.smallcaps}
  - [anger is heat]{.smallcaps}

Caressing the chest represents a gesture that could be interpreted as an attempt to hold the pressing anger inside (hence, an attempt to show patience). The biting/pressing of the lip/teeth could also indicate holding back pressure and pain. Difficulty to breath could be related to raising internal pressure pushing up the lungs.

- [Visual interference for anger]{.smallcaps} motivates the [anger is darkness]{.smallcaps} metaphor.

- [Standing body hair for anger]{.smallcaps} motivates the [(cause of) anger is annoyance]{.smallcaps}. Having a hair inside the body organ may represent potential disturbance to the person.

The social-based metonymies represent what Kövecses [-@kovecses_where_2015] suggests as non-embodied contexts and could motivate these metaphors:

- [Strong/aggresive verbal behaviour for anger]{.smallcaps} and [Aggressive visual behaviour for anger]{.smallcaps}

  - [anger is fierce, captive animal]{.smallcaps}
  - [anger is weapon]{.smallcaps}
  - [anger is (un)veiled object]{.smallcaps}

- [Violent frustrated behaviour for anger]{.smallcaps}; [crying for anger]{.smallcaps}

  - [anger is insanity]{.smallcaps}
  - [anger is adversary/opponent]{.smallcaps}
  - [anger is subjugator]{.smallcaps}

The qualitative analyses above offer some motivation for fifteen of the metaphors in the top-20 tables of the two approaches. These metaphors are based on characteristics that are metonymically associated with anger.

# Cultural model of [anger]{.smallcaps} {#cultural-model}

The cultural model of anger in Indonesian converges with the five-stage prototypical cultural model of anger (and emotions in general) in the cognitive linguistic literature [@holland_cognitive_1987, 210-214; @kovecses_where_2015, 84-85]. The aspects highlighted by the metaphorical mappings [@kovecses_metaphor_2000, 40-46] in the model correspond to the semantic dimensions of emotion from psychological studies [see @soriano_2013 that discusses (di/con)vergence between metaphorical meaning foci of anger and the dimensions of emotions]. For instance, the **Intensity** aspect [@kovecses_metaphor_2000, 41] corresponds to the dimension of **Arousal** [@soriano_2013, 415-416]. The **Negative/Positive** (or [**Un**]**desirability**) aspect [@kovecses_metaphor_2000, 44] corresponds to the dimension of **Valence**/**Pleasantness** [@soriano_2013, 417]. The cultural model of the concept [anger]{.smallcaps} in Indonesian unfolds as follows:

Stage 1: cause of anger (offending event)

The **Causation** aspect is an addition to Kövecses's [-@kovecses_metaphor_2000] list of aspects [see @soriano_2013, 416]. It provides the reason why anger exists. This aspect is predominantly construed as metaphorical events (see the list below, such as igniting fire, disturbing dormant animal, pulling the trigger), or a constant state of affairs (e.g., annoyance) [ @soriano_2013, 416; see also @heider_landscapes_1991, 81, finding that the cause of anger can be indicated by the "annoyance" cluster that he proposes.]:

  - annoyance
  - disturbing/harming dormant animal
  - touching/harming a person
  - pulling the trigger
  - igniting fire
  - inviting a person
  - seed/source of an organism

Stage 2: anger exists

The existential stage of anger contains three aspects: **Intensity**, **Evaluation**, and **Harm**. They could be metaphorically captured in two different ways: (i) separately by different mappings from a single metaphor (e.g., the [fierce, captive animal]{.smallcaps} metaphor can capture the Intensity and Harm aspects) [@soriano_2013, 415-418], or (ii) exclusively by one metaphor (e.g., the [darkness]{.smallcaps} metaphor only captures the negative Evaluation aspect). It is at this stage that anger exerts force to the experiencer (i) to become emotional, (ii) to experience the harmful effect of the force and exhibiting various physiological responses as shown by the metonymies, and eventually (iii) to attempt a retribution/reaction [@holland_cognitive_1987, 214; @kovecses_where_2015, 84-85] (see stage 5 below).

- aspect: Intensity

    The prototypical model of emotion postulates that, at this stage, the intensity tends to escalate and reach the limit the self is able to control [@kovecses_where_2015, 85]. The following mappings capture the Intensity:

    - fullness of, and increase pressure to, the substance
    - high degree of fire, and level of heat in the fluid
    - more quantity
    - aggressive behaviour and the attack of the animal
    - degree of effect of physical harm
    - amount of natural force and strength of effect
    - (extent of the) insane behaviour

- aspect: Evaluation 

    The Evaluative aspect of anger is prototypically negative [@soriano_2013, 416]. This includes the danger and unacceptability of the angry reaction to others and the self. They are metaphorically construed as:

    - bitter taste
    - being in the dark
    - intrinsic negative effect of the disease
    - strong and destructive natural force as an intrinsically negative force
    - affected/impeded motion and being confined

- aspect: Harm

    The Harm aspect relates to the psychological harm to the self and others. It is construed as the effect of physiological harm via the [emotional harm is physical damage]{.smallcaps} metaphor [@kovecses_metaphor_2000, 46], which is inherited by the more specific metaphorical mappings as follows:

    - danger of the adversary's attack
    - harmful effect of physical harm, disease, and destructive natural process
    - aiming weapon at others
    - insane behaviour
    - harm of the attack by the aggressive animal

Stage 3: attempt at control

Following the force-dynamic schema of emotion metaphors [@kovecses_metaphor_2000, 62-63], the rational self demonstrates a force tendency towards calmness. In doing so, the self attempts to resist and/or counterforce the emotional forces, including regulating the felt intensity and/or the expression (losing control of) emotion [@soriano_2013, 417]. This stage is captured by these mappings:

  - restraining captive animal
  - suppressing/impeding substance or fluid from going out
  - hiding the object
  - combating the opponent
  - avoiding confinement/impediment
  - maintaining sane/calm behaviour

If all the above attempts were successful and anger ceased before the self lost control, it would represent the non-prototypical model of anger scenarios: "Successful suppression", "Spontaneous cessation", and "Terminating event" [@holland_cognitive_1987, 215].

Stage 4: lacking and losing control

When the force of anger is too strong to control, the experiencer eventually loses control. These metaphorical mappings capture this aspect:

  - insane behaviour
  - reduced dimension of an object (shortage of emotional control/patience/calm)
  - being subjugated as an inferior object
  - losing/giving in to the adversary
  - unleashing the fierce, captive animal
  - unveiling the hidden object
  - explosion of the pressurised container
  - boiling over the heated fluid to overflow
  - being ravaged by the destructive natural force

The aspects **Difficulty to cope** and **Passivity** are also represented in this stage since loss of control over forces implies difficulty in counter-forcing them, resulting in the self being passive to the force (e.g., being subjugated, losing, being ravaged).

Stage 5: act of retribution

This stage represents the **Desire to act** (to others) aspect: a reaction as "a result of the emotion itself" [@kovecses_metaphor_2000, 45; @soriano_2013, 417], rather than the desire to possess anger. Metaphorical expressions from the following mappings differently capture construal of expressing and directing the anger towards the wrongdoer (retribution) or other parties.

  - releasing/channelling out the fluid at others
  - aiming the weapon at others as targets, and punishing others with the weapon

Lakoff and Kövecses [-@holland_cognitive_1987, 214] propose that "redirected anger" (i.e., non-retributive to the wrongdoer) is a non-prototypical extension. Below are examples of the redirected anger from the above mappings: 

(@chanelling_out_model) `r marah %>% filter(str_detect(CM_BROADER, 'substance in a '), str_detect(NODE_SENTENCES, 'melampiaskan.+musala')) %>% pull(NODE_SENTENCES)` (`r marah %>% filter(str_detect(CM_BROADER, 'substance in a '), str_detect(NODE_SENTENCES, 'melampiaskan.+musala')) %>% pull(FILES)`: `r marah %>% filter(str_detect(CM_BROADER, 'substance in a '), str_detect(NODE_SENTENCES, 'melampiaskan.+musala')) %>% pull(SENT_ID) %>% as.character()`)

(@retribution_model) `r marah %>% filter(str_detect(CM_BROADER, 'weapon'), str_detect(NODE_SENTENCES, 'sasaran.+Persiku')) %>% pull(NODE_SENTENCES)` (`r marah %>% filter(str_detect(CM_BROADER, 'weapon'), str_detect(NODE_SENTENCES, 'sasaran.+Persiku')) %>% pull(FILES)`: `r marah %>% filter(str_detect(CM_BROADER, 'weapon'), str_detect(NODE_SENTENCES, 'sasaran.+Persiku')) %>% pull(SENT_ID) %>% as.character()`)

The connection between the metaphor and the stages of the model tends to be one to many, as demonstrated by Soriano [-@soriano_2013]. A metaphor does not exclusively contribute to one stage, but possibly to different stages of the cognitive model. This is because the metaphorical mappings for a given metaphor can highlight different aspects, hence stages, in the model. For instance, the [fire]{.smallcaps} metaphor has the mapping indicating the cause of anger (as igniting the fire) (stage 1), the intensity of anger (high degree of heat) (stage 2), and intrinsically the danger of high extent of fire to the self and others (enacted at stage 5). Similarly, metaphorical mappings within the [fierce, captive animal]{.smallcaps} metaphor consist of, among others, restraining the animal captive (an attempt at control; stage 3), unleashing the captive animal (loss of control; stage 4), which can manifest in different reaction to the self or others (stage 5), and the attack of the animal to the victim that has implication to the harm aspect of anger.

# The role of context {#contexts}

## Situational context {#situational-context}

Kövecses [-@kovecses_metaphorcreativity_2019, 217-218; -@kovecses_metaphormindcontext_2019] proposes three sub-types of the situational context: the physical environment, the social situation, and the cultural context.

Geographically, Indonesia is the largest archipelago in the world, lying across the Equator and between the Indian and Pacific oceans. It has a year-round, relatively even tropical climate with two seasons, dry and wet. Geologically, Indonesia is located at the "Pacific Ring of Fire" (PRoF) [@britannica_ring_2020; @masum_pacific_2019]. The PRoF refers to a geographical area with "high volcanic and seismic activities within the edges of the Pacific Ocean" [@masum_pacific_2019, 1], meaning that it is "a site for frequent earthquakes and powerful volcanic eruptions" [@masum_pacific_2019, 1]. These two natural forces can be accompanied with tsunami warning or, worse, the tsunami itself [cf. @reid_history_2015]. There are more than 100 active volcanoes from the west to the eastern parts of Indonesia [@masum_pacific_2019, 3; @siebert_volcanoes_2011]. 

Such salient geographical and geological landscapes of Indonesia could plausibly motivate the use and comprehension of these metaphors: [natural force]{.smallcaps}, [fire]{.smallcaps}, [heated fluid]{.smallcaps}, and [temperature/hot-cold]{.smallcaps} (e.g., *kemarahan berubah __dingin__* 'anger becomes *cold*', *aku __kepanasan__ amarah* 'I *suffer the heat of* anger'; also in [§\@ref(heat-typebased)](#heat-typebased)). This study and Rajeg [-@rajeg_metafora_2013, 110-111] found singletons of expressions specifying anger as (lava in a) volcano, a sub-case of [heated fluid]{.smallcaps} metaphor: _**gunung api** kemarahan_ '*volcano* of anger' ([§\@ref(hotfluid-tokenbased)](#hotfluid-tokenbased)), _kemarahan seperti **lahar**_ 'anger be like *lava*', _**memuntahkan lahar** amarah_ '*puking the lava* of anger', and _amarah bagai **kepundan gunung**_ 'anger be like the *(lava) crater of mountain*' [@rajeg_metafora_2013, 110-111]. Moreover, the PRoF environment could motivate the [natural force]{.smallcaps} metaphor, evoked predominantly by expressions from the [natural disaster]{.smallcaps} and [destructive natural process]{.smallcaps} frames ([§\@ref(naturalforce-tokenbased)](#naturalforce-tokenbased)) [see also @fox_body_2018, 137, who found the construal of anger as a storm arising in the person in Rotenese of Eastern Indonesia; and @rajeg_metafora_2013, who found a statistical association between [natural force]{.smallcaps} metaphor and anger.]. Another evidence to link anger and its negativity to the destructive natural force comes from Reid's [-@reid_history_2015] historical study, which identified several uses of the phrase *gempa bumi* 'earthquakes lit. quake earth' and related expressions from the Malay Bible in the [*Malay Concordance Project*](https://mcp.anu.edu.au) [@reid_history_2015, 66]. These expressions are used to represent earthquake as manifestations of the wrath of God, and omens (following venerable Islamic and pre-Islamic local beliefs); Reid [-@reid_history_2015, 66] further notes that description about earthquakes appear prominently in the chronicles of Java and Bali, suggesting the long-standing awareness of such context of Indonesia physical environment. 

From the socio-cultural aspect, Indonesian tends to emphasise non-individualistic/group affiliation and social solidarity. This is a reflection of Indonesia's deeply rooted socio-cultural legacy called *gotong royong* 'lit. work together' [@simarmata_gotong_2020]. Such social-cultural consideration gives rise to the importance of empathy and the concealment of emotion in social context [@heider_cultural_2011, 10-11; @fox_body_2018, 137]. To maintain social harmony, concealment of emotion and reconciliation should be the primary goal, than hostile confrontation and aggressive expression. Such regulation of emotion is also related to politeness that can benefit social interaction [@prastuti_adaptation_2020]. This is consistent with Heider's study on Minangkabau and Javanese Indonesian speakers who "mask most anger, and the open expression of anger is strongly disapproved of and negatively sanctioned" [@heider_landscapes_1991, 80]. This context motivates the use of metaphors highlighting the attempt at emotional control and expression, such as the [(un)veiled object]{.smallcaps} metaphor [see also @matsuki_1995, 149, for similar socio-cultural context in Japanese to suppress their anger]. In Rotenese of Eastern Indonesia, the [(un)veiled object]{.smallcaps} metaphor is part of "ritual admonitions" offering counsel on anger (and other emotions such as fear, shame, and doubt), where the addressee is told not to reveal anger in the neck [@fox_body_2018, 136]. In addition to the metaphor, social-communicative behaviour metonymies, especially those denoting the expressive behaviours of anger, could also be motivated by the socio-cultural aspect.

## Discourse context {#discourse-context}

```{r surrounding-discourse-code}
marah %>% filter(duplicated(SENT_ID), USE == "metaphor") %>% pull(SENT_ID) -> dup_sent_metaphor
marah %>% filter(duplicated(SENT_ID)) %>% pull(SENT_ID) -> dup_sent_metaphor_metonymy
mixed_metaphor_patterns <- marah %>% filter(SENT_ID %in% dup_sent_metaphor) %>% arrange(desc(SENT_ID), CM_BROADER) %>% select(SENT_ID, FILES, NODE_SENTENCES, MP, MP_GLOSS, CM_BROADER) %>% group_by(SENT_ID, FILES) %>% mutate(n_metaphor_per_sentence = n_distinct(CM_BROADER)) %>% ungroup() %>% group_by(SENT_ID, FILES) %>% mutate(n_pattern_in_sentence = n()) %>% ungroup()
mixed_metaphor_metonymy_patterns <- marah %>% filter(SENT_ID %in% dup_sent_metaphor_metonymy) %>% arrange(desc(SENT_ID), CM_BROADER) %>% select(SENT_ID, FILES, NODE_SENTENCES, MP, MP_GLOSS, CM_BROADER)
```

One aspect of the discourse context is the "surrounding discourse", that is, how the cotext/linguistic context of the previous discourse influence, or is related to, the production of metaphor in the following discourse [@kovecses_metaphorcreativity_2019, 218-219]. One example is the use of similar conceptual metaphors in multiple constructions (e.g., noun phrase and argument-structure constructions) that are combined into a single utterances (typically at the sentence level) [cf. @sullivan_frames_2013 for the interplay between grammatical constructions and metaphor].  

(@discourse_ctx_fire) _Wajahnya yang riang menjadi **kemerah-merahan** karena **nyala** **api** kemarahan yang **membakar** dadanya_ (ind_mixed_2012_1M: 376378).

Example (@discourse_ctx_fire) illustrates the combination of metonymic pattern (in the main clause) and two metaphorical expressions for [anger is fire]{.smallcaps} (within the subordinate clause marked with *karena* 'because'). The use of [fire]{.smallcaps} metaphor in the noun phrase _**nyala api** kemarahan_ '*flame of the fire of* anger' could influence the forgoing discourse in the relative clause construction _kemarahan yang **membakar** dadanya_ 'anger that *burns* the chest'. In the context of the sentence, the two metaphors could be viewed as emphasising the specific reason for the metonymy [redness in the facial area for anger]{.smallcaps} used in the preceding, main clause. Let us see another example from [anger is substance in a container]{.smallcaps} ([Sections \@ref(contained-substance-tokenbased)](#contained-substance-tokenbased) and [\@ref(contained-substance-typebased)](#contained-substance-typebased))


(@discourse_ctx_substance) _Jika amarah tersebut tak **tersalurkan** atau ternetralisasi dengan permintaan maaf atau jiwa besar mengikhlaskan, yang akan terjadi selanjutnya adalah amarah itu **mengendap** dan semakin **mengeras** dalam batinnya._ (ind_newscrawl_2016_1M: 343033)

Sentence (@discourse_ctx_substance) contains more than one metaphorical expression that indicate a sequential, cause-and-effect scenario all within the same metaphorical frame, namely the [contained substance]{.smallcaps}. The sentence talks about the conserving effects of anger-substance if not being channelled out in the form of apology and big-heartedness. This shows how the use of a given metaphor in the preceding discourse indicating inability to channel out and neutralise anger, which is the cause, could influence the reasoning for the ensuing discourse indicating the effects of such cause using the same metaphor (i.e., becoming precipitated and hardened inside).

## Conceptual-cognitive context {#conceptual-context}

One aspect of the conceptual-cognitive context hinted by Kövecses [-@kovecses_metaphorcreativity_2019, 219-220; -@kovecses_metaphormindcontext_2019] is the **conventionality** of a given metaphor:

i.  the conventional association between a given source and target domains in the metaphorical conceptual system, and

i.  the conventionalised source-domain expression used to talk about certain aspect of the target domain. 

For the first point, Kövecses mentions [life is a journey]{.smallcaps} and [argument is war]{.smallcaps} metaphors with conventional relationship between their source and target domains in the long-term memory of the speakers. In the case of anger in Indonesian, Rajeg [-@rajeg_metafora_2013] has identified which source domains are statistically associated with anger (compared to the other emotions) ([§\@ref(previous-study-anger)](#previous-study-anger)). Such statistical association between the two domains could be assumed to reflect their conventional association, which needs further experimental verification. In addition to using statistical association to assess a metaphor's conventionality, Lakoff and Turner [-@lakoff_more_1989, 55] propose that a conceptual metaphor is considered conventionalised in a given language when "it underlies a range of everyday linguistic expressions". This proposal suggests the role of type frequency (i.e., the number of linguistic-types manifesting a metaphor) in measuring conventionality.

For the second point, Kövecses argues that the verb "defend" from the [war]{.smallcaps} domain is a conventionalised expression to express the meaning 'supporting an argument' (as in "*defending* an argument") in the target domain of [argument]{.smallcaps}. From the corpus-based perspective, the conventionalised linguistic expressions for a given aspect of, or meaning in, the target domain could be identified from the expression's frequency of occurrences in the corpus (e.g., how many times does a given source-domain LU, compared to the other, is used for a given aspect or meaning of the target) [see @stefanowitsch_words_2006, 68]. As an illustration, the most frequent (and potentially the default choice of) LU to express the causation aspect of anger via the [fire]{.smallcaps} frame ([§\@ref(fire-tokenbased)](#fire-tokenbased)) is based on the verb root *sulut* 'kindle/ignite', as in _**menyulutkan** [marah]{.smallcaps}_ '*kindle*/*ignite* anger' (45 tokens), rather than _**memantik** [marah]{.smallcaps}_ '*light up* anger' (3 tokens) or _**mencetuskan** [marah]{.smallcaps}_ '*ignite/light up* anger' (2 tokens).

Another type of conceptual-cognitive context is ideology, particularly religious ideology. Religious ideology and belief in Indonesia are very strong and have long been an integral part of Indonesian daily, socio-cultural life, since it is listed as the first principle in the nation's ideology *Pancasila* ('The Five Principles'), namely belief in the Supreme God. From the religious and spiritual perspective, anger is generally viewed negatively and dangerous [@bhide_anger_2007; @faizah_how_2021; @minhas_spiritual_2017]; this provides a plausible grounding for metaphors focusing on the negative valence and danger, namely [adversary]{.smallcaps}, [fierce, captive animal]{.smallcaps}, [subjugator]{.smallcaps}, [disease]{.smallcaps}, [darkness]{.smallcaps}, [insanity]{.smallcaps}, [evil creature]{.smallcaps} (e.g., *massa sudah __dirasuki__ amarah* 'the masses has been *possessed* by anger'), and [deceiver]{.smallcaps} (e.g., *__tipuan__/__godaan__ amarah* '*trickery*/*enticement* of anger') [@soriano_anger_2003, 118 also argues for the religio-cultural influence of Christianity on construing anger as [devil]{.smallcaps} in Spanish]. For instance, as a Balinese Hindu, in my elementary-school religion subject, I was taught that anger is one of the six enemies, the so-called *Sad Ripu* ('Six Enemies'), that humans need to manage or even defeat. This is a religious basis for the use of [adversary]{.smallcaps} and [subjugator]{.smallcaps} metaphors in construing anger [see also @faizah_how_2021 for the view from Islam; and @minhas_spiritual_2017, from the multi-religion perspective]. Moreover, the devastating effects of anger have been illustrated in various parts of the famous Hindu epic, the *Mahābhārata* [@bhide_anger_2007]. Another example is the religious-ideological view of anger as a disease, which is reflected in the notion of "Spiritual healing or medicine" [@minhas_spiritual_2017]. Such a healing can also be used, among others, for "anger management" and (literally) can "prevent the impact of disease by reducing bad feeling or anger" [@minhas_spiritual_2017, 168].

## Bodily context {#bodily-context}

```{r bodily-context}
non_bp <- c("jiwa", "pikiran", "batin", "ekspresi", "raut", "akal", "kalbu", "mental", "tatapan", "diri")
bp_meta_freq <- marah %>% 
  filter(!BODY_PART %in% non_bp, !is.na(BODY_PART)) %>% 
  count(BODY_PART, CM_BROADER, sort = TRUE)
bp_freq <- bp_meta_freq %>% 
  group_by(BODY_PART) %>% 
  summarise(n = sum(n)) %>% 
  arrange(desc(n)) %>% 
  mutate(eng = c("liver", "eyes", "chest", "heart", "crown of the head", "face", 
                 "head", "brain", "body", "mouth", "hand(s)", "body")) %>% 
  select(BODY_PART, eng, n)
```

The bodily context to be discussed concerns with the locus of emotion, which is related to the cultural situation and pre-modern religious practices in Indonesia. This study found that *hati* 'liver' is the predominant body-part term (`r pull(filter(bp_freq, BODY_PART == "hati"), n)` tokens) used as locus of emotion in a variety of metaphors (*X*^2^=`r round(chisq.test(bp_freq$n)$statistic, digit = 2)`, *df*=`r chisq.test(bp_freq$n)$parameter`, *p*~goodness~~-of-~~fit~`r pval_print(chisq.test(bp_freq$n)$p.value)`)^[The other body-part terms used in the metaphorical expressions are as follows (together with their token frequencies): `r bp_freq %>% filter(BODY_PART != "hati") %>% mutate(bp_eng_freq = paste("*", BODY_PART, "* '", eng, "' (", n, ")", sep = "")) %>% pull(bp_eng_freq) %>% paste0(., collapse = ", ")`.]. Siahaan [-@siahaan_did_2008] proposes that the liver divination ritual and the ethno-religious belief of *hati* 'liver' as the locus for the living soul could be the underlying cultural motivations for the importance of *hati* in the conceptualisation of emotion and cognition in Indonesian. This shows the sociocultural situatedness of embodiment in metaphorical conceptualisations of anger.

# Conclusions {#conclusions}

From combining the lexical (type-based) and corpus linguistic (token-based) approaches, this study reveals the dynamics (i.e., convergence and divergence) in the metaphors and metonymies of [anger]{.smallcaps} and their degree of salience. Metaphors attested in the lexical and the corpus-based approaches may differ in several respects. One example is in the different main meaning focus of the same metaphor in the two approaches, due to different productivity and presence of a given metaphorical mapping (e.g., the [pressurised substance in a container]{.smallcaps} and [fierce, captive animal]{.smallcaps} metaphors). Another example is the attestation of metaphors only in either approach. Such differences would also result in different degree of salience and ranking of the same metaphors.

This study also found that the metaphors strongly associated with anger in Rajeg's [-@rajeg_metafora_2013] corpus-based study ([§\@ref(previous-study-anger)](#previous-study-anger)) also make into the top-20 salience tables (i.e., the family of the [pressurised and heated substance]{.smallcaps}, the [heat/fire]{.smallcaps}, and the [natural force]{.smallcaps} metaphors), even though the relative salience of the metaphors in this study is contrasted for their occurrences with anger only (rather than with other emotions as in Rajeg [-@rajeg_metafora_2013] and Stefanowitsch [-@stefanowitsch_words_2006]). This study also offers new insights regarding the salient metonymies for anger in Indonesian that are not discussed in previous studies ([§\@ref(previous-study-anger)](#previous-study-anger)). Overall, the salience-based analyses offer a different perspective in capturing the prominence of metaphors and metonymies for anger by taking into account the central components of metaphor and metonymy in CMT, namely the extent of mappings and the linguistic expressions. 

Furthermore, the Indonesian prototypical cultural model of anger is largely correspond to the five-stage model proposed in previous work on anger in American English [@holland_cognitive_1987], and capture relevant semantic dimensions of emotions proposed in the psychological literature [@soriano_2013]. This study also identified examples of non-prototypical model of anger, such as the redirected anger and the metaphor suggesting concealment. 

Finally, this study argues for the different contexts as the motivating factors in the uses of several metaphors of anger. These contexts include the geographical and geological landscapes of Indonesia, the deeply rooted socio-cultural and religious beliefs of Indonesian, the conventional metaphors in the memory, and the socio-cultural situatedness of embodiment for the bodily locus of anger. The contextual dimension of metaphor usages is the missing aspect of previous works on anger metaphors in Indonesian.
